Just came across this:
 
 http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/england/lancashire/6322075.stm
 
 In brief, Britain's new Sexual Orientation Regulations would mean that you couldn't run a gays only hotel anymore, and the proprietor of such a hotel thinks this is a step backwards for gay rights.
 
 "We feel if we were forced to a situation where we had to accept heterosexual people into our hotel, our gay clientele will not behave as naturally as they would now."
 
 I can't say that I see his point. The quest for gay rights will be done when gay couples are treated just like any other couple. Part of that process is going to have to involve people actually seeing gays acting like other couples. That means seeing them on holiday, holding hands, kissing, doing all the stuff that couples do. If gays seclude themselves, the general public will never get educated. Likewise, gays will also need to learn that they don't need to hide themselves; that they can be who they are whenever and where ever they are. Granted, there are still a lot of places where being visibly gay will result in getting beaten, but a young couple's hotel that is known to be gay friendly is not likely to be one of them. The path to gay rights is through exposure and having gays and straights come closer together, not segregating them.

 My opinion:
 Actually, I think some businesses that market to gays only are exploitive. I have seen many XXXX places whose only appeal is "gay friendliness". There is an mentality among some gays that they only feel safe in gay friendly places. Some examples.
 
 I think some older people who grew up not knowing any other gays, let alone a gay hangout, relegate themselves to the figurative back of the bus and settle for seedy, but supportive places. Some very closeted types might fit this category. 
 
 I hate gay bars anymore. (I am also no longer young and cute and single and would look like a pathetic old fart.) I don't ever go to any bars anyway, but the gay bars in town are usually the sleaziest. It is amazing that we are willing to put up with these terrible places. The owners have a captive audience so they don't have to make it nice. 
 
 My partner and I were in DC last year. In Dupont Circle, there is a famous gay bookstore called Lambda Rising and we were checking it out. We asked the clerk for a good restaurant and he recommended some place because it was "safe" - he meant, you don't have to be closeted. My gosh, Dupont is the queerest section of DC (well not so much anymore) and you hardly have to alter your behavior there. We checked out the restaurant and it looked terrible - my partner thought it was too scary to even enter. 
 
 My point is, gays often have an internalized homophobia, and often remain closeted. We are willing to embrace anything that calls itself gay no matter how crappy. 
 
 In smaller cities, there are establishments that everyone knows are "gay ok" even if not exclusively gay. The guide books called them "mixed." There really is no such thing in the larger cities where gays are pretty much accepted everywhere. It is not like you have to have your rainbow flag waving and your "I'm a homo" t-shirt, but there are subtle clues that may outwardly suggest your sexuality, and those do not have to be concealed. 
 
 Kronus' initial post said it very well, but I do understand why some gays and lesbians would patronize gay-only establishments.
 
 (To address the initial news story, it is of course not OK to discriminate and exclude straights.)
